title: Match DNA Replication Enzymes to Functions
question: Create an interactive diagram game where undergraduate biology students match DNA replication enzymes to descriptions of their roles: helicase (unwinds double helix), primase (synthesizes RNA primer), DNA polymerase III (extends new strand), ligase (joins Okazaki fragments), topoisomerase (relieves supercoiling), and single-strand binding proteins (stabilize unwound DNA).

blueprint.title: DNA Replication Enzyme Challenge
blueprint.subject: Biology
blueprint.narrativeIntro: The cell is preparing to divide, and its DNA must be perfectly copied! Your mission is to identify the key enzymes involved in DNA replication and understand their critical roles in this complex process.
blueprint.completionMessage: Excellent work, Biologist! You've successfully navigated the intricate world of DNA replication enzymes and their vital functions.

diagram.assetPrompt: A detailed, interactive scientific diagram of a DNA replication fork. Clearly depict the unwound DNA double helix, showing the leading and lagging strands with their 5' and 3' ends. Distinct, labeled zones should be present for the placement of Helicase at the fork, Primase synthesizing primers, DNA Polymerase III extending strands, Ligase joining Okazaki fragments, Topoisomerase ahead of the fork, and Single-strand Binding Proteins stabilizing the separated strands. The diagram should visually suggest the direction of replication and the presence of Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand.

zones.label: Helicase
zones.description: Unwinds the DNA double helix by breaking the hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs, effectively separating the two strands to create the replication fork.

zones.label: Primase
zones.description: Synthesizes short RNA primers, providing the essential free 3'-OH group that DNA polymerase requires to initiate new DNA strand synthesis.

zones.label: DNA Polymerase III
zones.description: The primary enzyme responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands by adding complementary deoxyribonucleotides to the 3' end of an existing primer or growing DNA strand.

zones.label: Ligase
zones.description: Forms phosphodiester bonds to join DNA fragments, specifically connecting Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand and repairing nicks in the DNA backbone.

zones.label: Topoisomerase
zones.description: Relieves the torsional stress and supercoiling that builds up ahead of the replication fork as the DNA helix unwinds, preventing DNA damage and tangling.

zones.label: Single-strand Binding Proteins
zones.description: Binds to and stabilizes the separated single DNA strands, preventing them from re-annealing and protecting them from degradation until they can be used as templates.

config.instruction_text: Drag each enzyme to its primary location on the replication fork diagram where it performs its main function.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! That enzyme is correctly identified and placed.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Re-evaluate the function of this enzyme and its position at the replication fork.
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic! You've correctly identified and placed all the key enzymes at the replication fork.

misconceptions.message: Remember, DNA polymerase can only add nucleotides to an existing 3'-OH group; primase is required to synthesize a short RNA primer to provide this starting point.
Remember, DNA polymerase can only add nucleotides to an existing 3'-OH group; primase is required to synthesize a short RNA primer to provide this starting point.
Ligase's specific role is to form phosphodiester bonds between existing DNA fragments, sealing nicks, whereas DNA polymerase adds new nucleotides to extend a strand.
Topoisomerase primarily relieves the torsional stress (supercoiling) that builds up ahead of the replication fork as helicase unwinds the DNA, rather than directly unwinding the helix itself.
Topoisomerase primarily relieves the torsional stress (supercoiling) that builds up ahead of the replication fork as helicase unwinds the DNA, rather than directly unwinding the helix itself.

config.instruction_text: Now that you've placed each enzyme, match each one to its specific function by drawing a line from the description to the enzyme.

feedback.on_correct: Perfect match! That description accurately defines the enzyme's role.
feedback.on_incorrect: Hmm, that description doesn't quite fit. Consider the specific action of each enzyme at the replication fork.
feedback.on_completion: Outstanding! You've mastered the functions of these critical DNA replication enzymes.

Topoisomerase primarily relieves the torsional stress (supercoiling) that builds up ahead of the replication fork as helicase unwinds the DNA, rather than directly unwinding the helix itself.

descriptions.zone_helicase: Unwinds the DNA double helix by breaking the hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs, effectively separating the two strands to create the replication fork.
descriptions.zone_primase: Synthesizes short RNA primers, providing the essential free 3'-OH group that DNA polymerase requires to initiate new DNA strand synthesis.
descriptions.zone_dna_polymerase_iii: The primary enzyme responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands by adding complementary deoxyribonucleotides to the 3' end of an existing primer or growing DNA strand.
descriptions.zone_ligase: Forms phosphodiester bonds to join DNA fragments, specifically connecting Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand and repairing nicks in the DNA backbone.
descriptions.zone_topoisomerase: Relieves the torsional stress and supercoiling that builds up ahead of the replication fork as the DNA helix unwinds, preventing DNA damage and tangling.
descriptions.zone_single_strand_binding_proteins: Binds to and stabilizes the separated single DNA strands, preventing them from re-annealing and protecting them from degradation until they can be used as templates.
